segment.source: Create WMI Filters for the GPO (Windows 10)
segment.target: Create WMI Filters for the GPO (Windows 10)

segment.source: Create WMI Filters for the GPO
segment.target: Create WMI Filters for the GPO

segment.source: Create WMI Filters for the GPO
segment.target: Create WMI Filters for the GPO

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview
segment.target: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview

segment.source: To make sure that each GPO associated with a group can only be applied to devices running the correct version of Windows, use the Group Policy Management MMC snap-in to create and assign WMI filters to the GPO.
segment.target: To make sure that each GPO associated with a group can only be applied to devices running the correct version of Windows, use the Group Policy Management MMC snap-in to create and assign WMI filters to the GPO.

segment.source: Although you can create a separate membership group for each GPO, you would then have to manage the memberships of the different groups.
segment.target: Although you can create a separate membership group for each GPO, you would then have to manage the memberships of the different groups.

segment.source: Instead, use only a single membership group, and let WMI filters automatically ensure the correct GPO is applied to each device.
segment.target: Instead, use only a single membership group, and let WMI filters automatically ensure the correct GPO is applied to each device.

segment.source: To create a WMI filter that queries for a specified version of Windows
segment.target: To create a WMI filter that queries for a specified version of Windows

segment.source: To link a WMI filter to a GPO
segment.target: To link a WMI filter to a GPO

segment.source: Administrative credentials
segment.target: Administrative credentials

segment.source: To complete these procedures, you must be a member of the Domain Administrators group, or otherwise be delegated permissions to modify the GPOs.
segment.target: To complete these procedures, you must be a member of the Domain Administrators group, or otherwise be delegated permissions to modify the GPOs.

segment.source: First, create the WMI filter and configure it to look for a specified version (or versions) of the Windows operating system.
segment.target: First, create the WMI filter and configure it to look for a specified version (or versions) of the Windows operating system.

segment.source: To create a WMI filter that queries for a specified version of Windows
segment.target: To create a WMI filter that queries for a specified version of Windows

segment.source: Open the Group Policy Management console.
segment.target: Open the Group Policy Management console.

segment.source: In the navigation pane, expand Forest:YourForestName, expand Domains, expand YourDomainName, and then click WMI Filters.
segment.target: In the navigation pane, expand Forest:YourForestName, expand Domains, expand YourDomainName, and then click WMI Filters.

segment.source: Click Action, and then click New.
segment.target: Click Action, and then click New.

segment.source: In the Name text box, type the name of the WMI filter.
segment.target: In the Name text box, type the name of the WMI filter.

segment.source: Note: Be sure to use a name that clearly indicates the purpose of the filter.
segment.target: Note: Be sure to use a name that clearly indicates the purpose of the filter.

segment.source: Check to see if your organization has a naming convention.
segment.target: Check to see if your organization has a naming convention.

segment.source: In the Description text box, type a description for the WMI filter.
segment.target: In the Description text box, type a description for the WMI filter.

segment.source: For example, if the filter excludes domain controllers, you might consider stating that in the description.
segment.target: For example, if the filter excludes domain controllers, you might consider stating that in the description.

segment.source: Click Add.
segment.target: Click Add.

segment.source: Leave the Namespace value set to rootCIMv2.
segment.target: Leave the Namespace value set to rootCIMv2.

segment.source: In the Query text box, type:
segment.target: In the Query text box, type:

segment.source: This query will return true for devices running at least Windows Vista and Windows Server 2008.
segment.target: This query will return true for devices running at least Windows Vista and Windows Server 2008.

segment.source: To set a filter for just Windows 8 and Windows Server 2012, use "6.2%".
segment.target: To set a filter for just Windows 8 and Windows Server 2012, use "6.2%".

segment.source: To specify multiple versions, combine them with or, as shown in the following:
segment.target: To specify multiple versions, combine them with or, as shown in the following:

segment.source: To restrict the query to only clients or only servers, add a clause that includes the ProductType parameter.
segment.target: To restrict the query to only clients or only servers, add a clause that includes the ProductType parameter.

segment.source: To filter for client operating systems only, such as Windows 8 or Windows 7, use only ProductType="1".
segment.target: To filter for client operating systems only, such as Windows 8 or Windows 7, use only ProductType="1".

segment.source: For server operating systems that are not domain controllers, use ProductType="3".
segment.target: For server operating systems that are not domain controllers, use ProductType="3".

segment.source: For domain controllers only, use ProductType="2".
segment.target: For domain controllers only, use ProductType="2".

segment.source: This is a useful distinction, because you often want to prevent your GPOs from being applied to the domain controllers on your network.
segment.target: This is a useful distinction, because you often want to prevent your GPOs from being applied to the domain controllers on your network.

segment.source: The following clause returns true for all devices that are not domain controllers:
segment.target: The following clause returns true for all devices that are not domain controllers:

segment.source: The following complete query returns true for all devices running Windows 8, and returns false for any server operating system or any other client operating system.
segment.target: The following complete query returns true for all devices running Windows 8, and returns false for any server operating system or any other client operating system.

segment.source: The following query returns true for any device running Windows Server 2012, except domain controllers:
segment.target: The following query returns true for any device running Windows Server 2012, except domain controllers:

segment.source: Click OK to save the query to the filter.
segment.target: Click OK to save the query to the filter.

segment.source: Click Save to save your completed filter.
segment.target: Click Save to save your completed filter.

segment.source: To link a WMI filter to a GPO
segment.target: To link a WMI filter to a GPO

segment.source: After you have created a filter with the correct query, link the filter to the GPO.
segment.target: After you have created a filter with the correct query, link the filter to the GPO.

segment.source: Filters can be reused with many GPOs simultaneously; you do not have to create a new one for each GPO if an existing one meets your needs.
segment.target: Filters can be reused with many GPOs simultaneously; you do not have to create a new one for each GPO if an existing one meets your needs.

segment.source: Open theGroup Policy Management console.
segment.target: Open theGroup Policy Management console.

segment.source: In the navigation pane, find and then click the GPO that you want to modify.
segment.target: In the navigation pane, find and then click the GPO that you want to modify.

segment.source: Under WMI Filtering, select the correct WMI filter from the list.
segment.target: Under WMI Filtering, select the correct WMI filter from the list.

segment.source: Click Yes to accept the filter.
segment.target: Click Yes to accept the filter.
